claim: Coughing mimics the effects of CPR during a heart attack, making it effective in stopping a heart attack.

supporting.text: Coughing increases intrathoracic pressure, which can temporarily maintain blood flow to the brain during a cardiac arrest, similar to CPR.

attacks.text: Coughing increases intrathoracic pressure, which can temporarily maintain blood flow to the brain during a cardiac arrest, similar to CPR.

CPR is designed to provide consistent blood flow, whereas coughing is irregular and cannot ensure adequate circulation.
Studies have shown that coughing alone is insufficient to maintain the necessary blood pressure during a cardiac arrest.
Even in controlled settings, coughing has not been proven to significantly improve survival rates compared to standard CPR.
The American Heart Association does not recommend coughing as a substitute for CPR in most cases of cardiac arrest.
